newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN VTM TO CLAIM DAMAGES IF AD MONOPOLY LIFTED.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN VTM TO CLAIM DAMAGES IF AD MONOPOLY LIFTED.

text.p: The Belgian VTM commercial TV channel will claim 15 to 20 billion francs ($421 and $562 million) in damages from the Flemish regional government if it loses its advertising monopoly, chairman Rik De Nolf said on Wednesday.
The European Commission is expected to tell Belgium on Thursday it must scrap the advertising monopoly granted to VTM or face legal action.
"That would mean that damages will be asked for breaching the agreement which was based on an 18-year exclusive right to advertising income from television in Flanders," De Nolf told BRTN radio.
"The amount could be between 15 and 20 billion francs, or even more," he said.
VTM is 44 percent owned by Dutch publishing group VNU .

In 1989 VTM was given an 18-year advertising monopoly for Dutch-speaking Flanders, in northern Belgium, which has been attacked by rival channel VT4 owned by Nasdaq-listed TV group Scandinavian Broadcasting System (SBS) .
VT4 has been forced to set up headquarters in London to circumvent VTM's monopoly and to be able to broadcast to Flanders.
The channel started operations in February 1995 despite the opposition of the Flemish regional government and took the issue to the Commission the same year.
